messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.
It looks like the location service is currently disabled, so I can’t determine your current city. Would you like me to turn the location service on so I can check where you are?

messages.name: set_location_service_status
messages.content: PermissionError: Location service cannot be turned on in low battery mode

It seems the device is currently in low battery mode, and the location service can’t be enabled while that mode is active. Would you like me to turn off low battery mode first so I can then enable the location service?
Yeah, go ahead and do that.

Great — I’ve turned off low battery mode and enabled the location service. Now, to determine your city, I’ll still need your current latitude and longitude. Could you share those coordinates (they might be provided by your device’s GPS, for example), or would you prefer to look them up another way?
I'm not sure how to do that right now. Can you figure it out?

Unfortunately, I don’t have a function that can automatically pull your device’s live GPS coordinates—I need the latitude and longitude values from you (or from another app on your device that can read GPS).  

If you’re on a smartphone, you can usually:
- **iPhone**: Open the built-in “Maps” app, tap the blue location dot, and you’ll see “Lat, Long” listed.  
- **Android**: Open Google Maps, tap and hold on the blue dot that shows your location, and the coordinates will appear in the search box at the top.

Once you give me those two numbers, I’ll take care of the rest and tell you what city they belong to!
I don't have access to that info right now. What else can we try?

A few ideas that don’t rely on your phone’s live GPS:

1. Public IP-based geolocation  
   If you’re on a computer/phone that’s connected to the internet, you can open a browser and go to a site like https://whatismyipaddress.com or https://ipinfo.io. These pages usually display your approximate city based on your public IP address. You could just read the city off the screen.

2. Check Wi-Fi network name or router/admin page  
   Sometimes the SSID (network name) or the ISP’s router-status page lists the service address. If you’re on a home or hotel Wi-Fi, the ISP’s name can provide a very strong clue about the city.

3. Ask another app  
   If you use any weather, ride-share, or delivery apps that already have location permission, those apps often mention the city in their UI (e.g., “Delivering in Los Angeles”). You could open one of them and glance at the displayed location.

If any of those lead you to a latitude/longitude pair—or even just a city name—let me know and I can cross-confirm it for you.
I'm not sure how to do those right now. Can you try something else?

I'm afraid I have run out of options on my side.  
The only tools I have for determining your city rely on either:

1. The coordinates you provide (so I can look up the address with the search_lat_lon function), or  
2. An external source (like an IP-geolocation site or another app) that tells you the city, which you can then read to me.

Without at least one of those pieces of data, I simply don’t have any other built-in way to discover where you are. If you later get access to any approximate city name or any lat/long pair—even ballpark values—just let me know and I’ll be happy to look it up for you!
